text: Secretary of State what do you say to
patients and NHS staff at this time of
extraordinary pressure on them well the
first thing I want to say is thank you
to the staff for the NHS who are working
under extraordinary pressure the figures
we've had out this week show that we had
the busiest day in NHS history in
December and for staff on the frontline
that means they get extraordinarily
tired a lot of mental emotional pressure
a lot of time away from their families
and we although then a great debt for
the fantastic work they do and I want to
recognize that what they ask me is what
are you doing to help relieve that
pressure and a lot has happened in
recent years every any Department in the
country has around ten more doctors
compared to six years ago about hundred
more nurses in every hospital trust but
when you look at the scale of demand
that we've got the increase in demand
that's happening we clearly need a much
more profound change than that which is
why we have embarked on a big programme
of transformation how's it going I think
some bits are going very well I think we
have good plans in place to improve the
capacity of our GP system we need to
deliver those plans we're making good
progress on mental health cancer
survival rates are going up but other
bits are disappointingly slow the
integration of the health and social
care system that pressures on social
care there are those areas where we
clearly need to do more as the Prime
Minister acknowledged this week but you
may have plans but the pressure is right
here right now those plans don't seem to
be helping do they well right here right
now we have for example this year put
nearly 4 billion pounds of extra funding
into the NHS which is just to give you
an idea of the scale of that that is
more than the cost the entire cost of
the fire service just as an increase to
NHS funding this year but even with that
the system's under huge pressure it is
and that's why it isn't just about money
and I would say that
one of the things that we need to do
better at is learning from the air need
apartments that have been coping well we
can see very good practice in trusts
like South works sure Dorset Luton and
Dunstable and we haven't been as good as
we should have been in spreading that
best practice around the system I think
there are also delays in terms of the
links to the social care system and you
know it's been difficult discharging
people and we need to look at those
problems and that is all work that's
happening the UK spends a lower share of
its national income than France and
Germany and some other leading nations
haven't used the government got to face
up to spending more money I think on
spending there is a a short-term and a
long-term issue in in the short term and
long term spending per head falls
doesn't it on current projection well
that's not correct actually over the key
ifs yeah but over the period of this
parliament the NHS specifically said
could they have a big increase at the
start of the parliament so that they can
get going on some of the changes they
want happening but then a flatter
profile during the rest of the
Parliament if you look at France and
Germany to answer the direct question I
mean on the measures that the OECD
publish
I think of 35 measures there are 14
where we do better than France and
Germany this winter France had a million
people with flu Germany had cities where
entire any departments in every hospital
were closed on certain night so where I
would disagree with some of the
suggestions in your coverage is the idea
this is a problem unique to the NHS we
are all grappling with the profound
changes caused by an aging population
and by consumers who have much higher
expectations and I think we won stood
absolutely right to scrutinize the
problems that we face in the NHS
we also have a duty to recognize some of
the successes I mean this week for
example we discovered that half the
number of children are dying from cancer
compared to 1990 now that is a huge
success for the NHS incredibly important
to every family with young children we
we also discovered four heart attacks
that we've nearly doubled the number of
people being seen within 90 minutes so
there are some very important positive
things happening but in terms of what's
happening now in A&E units the BBC has
shown images from Royal Blackburn of
people waiting 13 hours mothers and
babies sitting in the corridor on you
embarrass to burn that well it is you
know incredibly frustrating for me I'm
doing this job because I want NHS care
to be the safest and best in the world
and that kind of care is completely
unacceptable no one would want it for
members of their own family but it's
happening in a hospital rated good well
so what can you do about it yes I think
you have to recognize is that overall
there are positive things as well as
negative things and there is huge
commitment in the NHS to sort out those
negative things and the particular
pressure point we have is any and what
we need to do is to find ways of
treating particularly people with
complex conditions older people with
dementia treating them at home or in the
community and that is the big direction
of change that we've embarked on but
that is longer-term what we're seeing in
hospitals right now is the sort of
scenes we've been showing on the BBC
this week real stress real strain the
figures out show performance targets the
worst since 2004 what can you do about
it right now shouldn't you be doing more
I think it's wrong to suggest to people
that these profound challenges such as
we face with an aging population are
ones where there's a silver bullet that
you can solve the problem over now we
have a very good plan it has the support
of the NHS it will take time to deliver
but in terms of immediate support we're
doing what we can with extra financial
support to the NHS this year more
doctors more nurses but we also need to
row in behind people
in the NHS are working very hard to try
and sort out these problems and we also
need the public's help because we know
that a number of the people who are seen
in Enys could actually have their needs
dealt with in another part of the NHS
and we need to make sure that as far as
we can with free up people in any
departments to deal with the most
vulnerable older patients who have
particular needs there been cuts to
social care funding under your
government hasn't that created the
problem that we're now seeing and what
do you say to the family of Iris Sibley
featured on the Today programme she had
to wait 6 months in a hospital before
she could get a place in a care well I
don't want to make any kind of excuses
for that it is totally unacceptable
it is terrible for mrs. Sibley but it's
also very bad for the NHS because other
people could have but it's not the case
of its kind no and as I say there are no
excuses it is completely unacceptable
what I would say is on Social Care but
Prime Minister's be very clear we
recognise the pressures there we
recognise there is a problem about the
sustainability of the social care system
and that has to be addressed and we're
going to do that more money in the
budget well that's for the Chancellor
and the prime minister but you know look
at what the prime minister said this
week this is an area where there is
pressure and if we're going to have a
solution it needs to be a long-term
sustainable solution and not a quick fix
so do state thank you very much thank
you thank you
